image.altText: Vaping products stacked next to each other on display

items.synopsis: Twelve businesses have been fined as part of a crackdown on the illegal sale of nicotine vapes in SA, which involved the seizure of almost 5,000 e-cigarettes.

title.children: Vapes hidden in pizza boxes among 5,000 seized in SA crackdown on illegal e-cigarettes

image.altText: A dark-haired man in his 30s and his mother, about 60, sit in front of a tent with their two dogs.

items.synopsis: Matt Turner has a job and perfect tenancy references, but the housing crisis has left him at his lowest point.

title.children: 'It's hard living in a tent and going to work every day': Why this employed 34yo and his mum are homeless

image.altText: DeanYates

items.synopsis: WikiLeaks leaked a video showing two of former foreign correspondent Dean Yates's colleagues being killed. The truth left him reeling.

title.children: WikiLeaks leaked a video showing two of Dean's colleagues being killed. The truth left him reeling

image.altText: Greens party members Max Chandler-Mather and Adam Bandt at a press conference.

items.synopsis: The federal government's key housing policy is set to pass parliament after a deal was reached with the Greens.

title.children: Government's key housing policy set to pass parliament after deal with Greens

image.altText: A Canberra NRL player looks at a referee who is holding his hands crossed in an 'X' shape.

items.synopsis: Incoming South Sydney signing Jack Wighton is facing a lengthy NRL ban if found guilty of biting Newcastle's Tyson Gamble in his final game for Canberra.

title.children: Jack Wighton biting charge goes straight to NRL judiciary

image.altText: premier gesturing as she speaks, behind a lecturn

items.synopsis: Cabinet members have had to defend the premier's leadership from chatter about dissatisfaction among Labor colleagues.

title.children: Queensland Premier 'absolutely determined' to lead Labor after rumours of dissatisfaction in party ranks

image.altText: Oxfam office

items.synopsis: With unions embedding trials of the four-day work week in industrial agreements, is this the moment the working-hour-reducing concept goes mainstream?

title.children: Four-day week enshrined in first Australian union agreement, with concept spreading

image.altText: Bird's eye view of cramped island nation

items.synopsis: Experts say the sea will engulf Carti Sugtupu and dozens of neighbouring islands in the Guna Yala region by the end of the century.

title.children: 'We're going to sink': Residents escape island hit by rising sea levels

image.altText: A woman smiles, she wears a black and orange top with indigenous art. She has short hair and sits in a chair, with crafts

items.synopsis: Cheryl Norris says she doesn't feel like a prisoner in her own home now she has a space to craft in. It was set up by a couple who moved to the Riverland after a flood in their hometown.

title.children: How a craft shop is connecting and making people 'feel good'

image.altText: A woman in black tights measures her hips with a red measuring tape

items.synopsis: We've known for some time the body mass index is an inaccurate measuring stick for assessing someone's weight and health. So why is such an imperfect tool still being used, and what should we use instead, asks Rachael Jefferson-Buchanan.

title.children: Doctors' over-reliance on BMI may be harming patients' health. Here's what we should test instead

image.altText: An illustration of a car, house, health kit and book in an opened gift box

items.synopsis: Some experts say a salary sacrifice or a salary package agreement can help maximise income and reduce tax debt — depending on the industry you're in and what your employer offers.

title.children: Ever heard of salary sacrifice? Here's what it is and how it can help reduce debt

image.altText: A man wearing a suit jacket and sunglasses walks outside the court building.

items.synopsis: A jury has been dismissed after hearing months of evidence in the trial of Cecil Kennedy, who prosecutors alleged had given Jordan Thompson a dose of Endep because he wanted to keep him quiet.

title.children: Jurors fail to reach verdict for man accused of giving toddler lethal dose of antidepressants

image.altText: A young boy looking at the camera while kneeling near a pile of rubble.

items.synopsis: Everyone left in Moulay Ibrahim has a story of their narrow escape — just ask 11-year-old Abdarazak Abou Aalam, whose tragic tour of the town starts at his neighbour's house, which was destroyed in Friday's earthquake.

title.children: In this devastated Moroccan village, an 11yo earthquake survivor gives a tour of the rubble

image.altText: A middle-aged man of Indian heritage in a black suit speaks against a dark backdrop.

items.synopsis: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has chastised China's premier for "unacceptable" interference in British democracy, after a newspaper reported that a parliamentary researcher was arrested earlier this year on suspicion of spying for Beijing.

title.children: British PM chides China after report parliamentary staffer spying for Beijing

image.altText: Composite Kerry Frankcombe and marine rescue personnel.

items.synopsis: Conditions were good when Kerry Frankcombe set out for a Sunday afternoon fishing trip off Tasmania's north coast, police say. But the 75-year-old has not been since, despite his boat being found with an EPIRB not activated.

title.children: Empty boat found at sea after Tasmanian man embarks on fishing trip

image.altText: A plume of smoke from a bushfire, with a dry paddock in the foreground.

items.synopsis: Fire and emergency services are working to contain a fire burning through national parkland south of Bundaberg that prompted an emergency evacuation alert earlier today.

title.children: Fire crews continue to battle blaze in national park after emergency bushfire evacuation south of Bundaberg

image.altText: A police vehicle and officer in front of police tape at the side of a lake

items.synopsis: A body has been recovered from Stockton Lake, near Collie, but it is yet to be formally identified, as the search for a missing 23-year-old man continues.

title.children: Body found at popular WA swimming spot amid search for missing man

image.altText: Novak Djokovic holds up his hands

items.synopsis: Novak Djokovic is 36 years old, has won more grand slam singles titles than any other man in history with 24 to his name — but incredibly, he's still learning and hungry for more.

title.children: The ominous sentence that shows newly crowned US Open champion Novak Djokovic is not done yet

image.altText: Ashton Kutcher and Mila Kunis appear in a video apologising.

items.synopsis: Four of Danny Masterson's That '70s Show cast mates wrote character letters in support of the convicted rapist, including Ashton Kutcher and Mila Kunis.

title.children: Ashton Kutcher, Mila Kunis face growing backlash over Danny Masterson support

image.altText: Peter Payne stands in front of a gate

items.synopsis: A magistrate calls bush solicitor Peter Payne's crime "unsophisticated" but says it crossed the line.

title.children: 'They're setting a trap for you': NSW publican-turned-lawyer convicted after helping client avoid court

image.altText: Novak Djokovic holds a silver trophy

items.synopsis: Novak Djokovic extends his dominance in men's tennis with a straight-sets victory over Daniil Medvedev to claim his 24th grand slam singles title and his fourth at the US Open.

title.children: 'What are you still doing here?': Dominant Djokovic wins record-equalling US Open title

image.altText: A brown snake with its tongue out on a rock

items.synopsis: Experts say how you respond in the minutes after a snake bite could be the difference between life and death. It comes after the tragic death of a man bitten by a suspected brown snake while trying to save a friend in North Queensland.

title.children: Snake season has turned deadly. Here's what to do if you get bitten

image.altText: A man with a moustache and nose ring wearing a hat leans against a tree trunk.

items.synopsis: As Australians prepare to vote in a historic referendum, the ABC's Voice correspondent Dan Bourchier travels to the north, west and east of the country for Four Corners and finds a nation grappling with its future.

title.children: Ben was going to vote Yes to the Voice. Now he's a hard No

image.altText: an aerial view of an outback bushfire

items.synopsis: Authorities have been going door-to-door in parts of the town of Tennant Creek warning residents that a major bushfire could spread to the town amid extreme fire conditions.

title.children: Tennant Creek residents warned to prepare as major bushfire burns closer to outback town

image.altText: planes on an airport runway

items.synopsis: Qantas' board remains under pressure ahead of its annual report, including over whether former CEO Alan Joyce should receive his full bonus, and what the board knew about the ACCC's ghost flights investigation. Meanwhile, the ASX is slightly higher. Follow live.

title.children: Qantas board under pressure over Joyce bonus and ghost flights, tech stocks await iPhone 15 release, ASX up

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Last week ABS data showed there's a record number of people working two or more jobs right now to make ends meet. If that sounds like you or someone you know, we want to hear from you, too. Get in touch with my colleague David Chau by emailing him at Chau.David@abc.net.au, or slide into his DMs on Twitter:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 📣 If you're working two or more jobs, we want to hear from you

children.content: Last week ABS data showed there's a record number of people working two or more jobs right now to make ends meet.
If that sounds like you or someone you know,
we want to hear from you
, too.
Get in touch with my colleague
David Chau
by emailing him at
Chau.David@abc.net.au
, or slide into his DMs on Twitter:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Tabcorp has resolved an income tax treatment dispute with the ATO over "various licenses and authorities" that will see the company receive a $45 million after-tax benefit at the end of the 2024 financial year. Under the settlement, Tabcorp will be refunded around $83 million, which accounts for 20% of the disputed tax liabilities and interest, while the proceedings brought by the ATO will also be dismissed. Tabcorp will pay around $37 million to The Lottery Corporation (TLC) as part of a separation deed between the two companies, dated March 25 last year. All up, Tabcorp says it will see a post-tax benefit of approximately $45 million in its financial statements at the end of the 2024 financial year, and will be treated as a significant item.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tabcorp resolves dispute with ATO, to receive post-tax benefit of $45 million

at the end of the 2024 financial year.

Tabcorp will

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: For those of you who are keen observers of the Aussie dollar, you'll have seen that it's picked up some ground during trade today — it's up around 0.9 to 1%, hovering at around 64.36 US cents. It's been a week since the Aussie dollar was above that 64 US cent mark, and although it's edging slightly higher, it hasn't cracked the 65 US cent mark since mid-August. So what's behind today's increase? A stronger Japanese yen, in response to comments by the Bank of Japan's governor Kazuo Ueda, who flagged Japan could soon have enough data to end negative interest rates. That bounce has also been helped by China's consumer prices returning to positive territory, rising by 0.1% in August from a year earlier, which is a sign the economy might be stabilising with an easing of deflationary pressures. But investors are still nervous about the US inflation data coming out later this week (Wednesday, to be precise), and whether the Federal Reserve is finished with rate hikes or more may be on the horizon — which will then ripple through the global economy.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The Aussie dollar is moving higher today, and it's partly thanks to Japan's central bank

image.altText: AFL players playing a game

items.synopsis: Two men have been charged with assaulting police officers after spectators stormed the field at a country footy final in Queensland.

title.children: Police officers allegedly assaulted after 'disgusting' incident at outback Australian Rules grand final

image.altText: An Indigenous man and a teenager stand next to each other in playground.

items.synopsis: Some of Yardgee's players have gone from "getting into a lot of trouble" to celebrating premiership glory. But a post-game spectator brawl has cast a cloud over their success.

title.children: Footballers sick of violence ruining the game call on elders, parents to step up

image.altText: A concrete water tank lies unused in a paddock

items.synopsis: A report commissioned by Newcrest Cadia finds lead matching the mine's isotopic signature in 40 per cent of tank sludge samples taken from Orange district rainwater tanks.

title.children: Lead 'fingerprints' found in rainwater tanks match gold mine's ore

image.altText: Coco Gauff

items.synopsis: The 19-year-old is the first teen to win the grand slam since Serena Williams in the 90s.

title.children: Negative comments add gas to Coco Gauff's fire in US Open final

image.altText: Crime figure Gavin Preston looks unsmilingly into the camera as he poses for a photo.

items.synopsis: Police continue to search for two men after a fatal shooting at a Keilor cafe, as CBD traders raise fears about Melbourne's reputation.

title.children: Search continues for two offenders after fatal cafe shooting of underworld figure Gavin Preston

image.altText: A dingo looks out from atop a hill

items.synopsis: Rangers are pleading with visitors to K'gari to heed warnings about dingoes ahead of school holidays as another one is destroyed due to its dangerous interactions with humans.

title.children: Rangers euthanase dingo involved in high-risk attacks, the third to be destroyed this year

image.altText: A man and woman hugging in front of a for sale sign at a house

items.synopsis: China made it much harder for money to leave the country in 2017. Our study looked at Sydney home prices before and after that crackdown — and these are the suburbs where we found they changed, writes Song Shi.

title.children: How much did Chinese investors drive up Sydney home prices?

image.altText: A young person is laying on top of a bed with over-ear headphones on and a tablet laying on their chest.

items.synopsis: There's a colour of noise for every mood. But are these sounds really useful for getting to sleep, or concentrating better? That depends on you.

title.children: White noise might help you learn a new language, but be wary of other claims around coloured noise

image.altText: A woman smiles at the camera holding up a big tray of animal treats.

items.synopsis: With her all-woman workforce and biscuits that look good enough for humans to eat, Emma Gibbons is breaking into a multi-billion-dollar global market of animal lovers splurging on spoiling their pets.

title.children: Iced doggie doughnuts and pony treats catapult Emma into a multi-billion-dollar market
